Problem:
Assume the function \( z(t) \) governed by the complex differential equation \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \) where \( \omega \) is a real number, represents a physical process. We explore the effects of the operation \( h(z) = e^{kt}z \) on \( z(t) \), with \( k \) being another real constant.

When the transformation \( h(z) \) is applied at time \( t=0 \) on an initial condition \( z_0 \) and then evolved according to \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \) for a time period \( T \), will the resulting \( z(T) \) be equivalent to the instance where \( z_0 \) is directly evolved by \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \) for the same period?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \( h(z) \) alters \( z_0 \) to \( e^{k \cdot 0} z_0 = z_0 \), but as t progresses, the factor \( e^{kt} \) scales and rotates \( z(t) \) differently as compared to purely evolving under \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \), leading to a varying trajectory and therefore a different final state at \( t=T \).
